characters: A FRONT DOOR ON THE STREET
A BUBBLING BROOK BY A TINY WATERFALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's seven o'clock and the birds are singing in the trees outside an old, two-story frame house with a sagging fron porch and peeling white paint, anly half-covered by a par paint job. MRS, NOONAN (v.0.) (shouting cheerily) Let's go kids! Rise and shine! Let's hit the deck! Let's go-go-go! A dog begins BARKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doors fly open and a half dozen children start pouring in the hall, racing for the bathroom, and rough~-housing dow the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: She stands at the foot of the stairs calling up to the ga of kids. She's a plump, cheerful woman with a helpful, supportive manner. The family COLLIE runs up the stairs still BARKING.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: {calling out) Up, up, up! Andy? Billy? I'm not hearing any movement up there! Make sure Danny's up, please, Uppie- uppie everybody!

dialogues.speaker: INT, DANNY NOONAN'S BEDROOM
dialogues.text: The first light of day filters through the window reveali an incredibly messy boy's bedroom littered with dirty lau books, comics, breken toys and an electric guitar. The wa are covered with KISS posters, framed athletic awards and cheesy trophies on a homemade bookshelf, Little League te pictures and a poster-sized blow-up of John Belushi. A br model spaceship dangles from a thread from the ceiling fi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three brothers share the room. ANDY and BILLY, twelve and thirteen are getting dressed. DANNY NOONAN, age eighteen, sits on the cdge of his bed rubbing his eyes. He's a manl good-looking, athletic kid with a kind of quick, natural intelligence -- the oldest and biggest of the Noonan kids

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (shouts) I'm up. He hops out of bed and heads for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: BILLY, ED and KATHLEEN are already lined up at the bathro door, waiting impatiently in their pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (impatiently) Who's in there?

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: Danny, will you tell Nancy to get out of there?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: She's been in there an hour! Danny goes right to the bathroom door, knocks once and ba catching twelve year old NANCY in her panties, her mother rouge and lipstick smeared on her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Come on, Nance!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: {screams) Danny! She grabs her robe and runs out.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (off camera) Mother! Danny saw me naked!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: There's not much to see. Danny puts some Crest on his toothbrush and leaves the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: As Danny comes out; Billy, Ed and Kathleen fight to get i next.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: I'm next! I called it!

dialogues.speaker: KATHLEEN
dialogues.text: (pushing him) Oh no you don't!

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Shotgun! Danny heads back to his bedroom and almost trips over a t year old sitting on a potty.

dialogues.speaker: THREE YEAR OLD
dialogues.text: I'm pooping, Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (laughs) I'm proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. NOONAN, Danny's father, is trying to eat breakfast an read the newspaper while the kids pop in and out of the room. He loves his children, but over the years, with eac new addition to the family, he's come to feel more and mo - like a forgotten guest in his own home. Danny comes through the dining room on his way to the kit

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad. Can I ---

dialogues.speaker: MR. NOONAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (protesting) You didn't even hear ---

dialogues.speaker: MR. NOONAN
dialogues.text: Whatever it is -- no! Danny goes through the open door into the kitchen unfazed his father's churlishness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. NOONAN is busy making fried egg sandwiches. A crying four year old clings to her apron while other kids pillag the refrigerator, spill milk and orange juice, and slop cereal into bowls. The dog is barking, the phone is ringi and the radio plays loudly. Danny gets a bowl and spoon f the cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: -- aS soon as you guys get back from Little League, maybe we can get some painting done on the house. Thirteen year old SAM runs in and grabs a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: The Douglases got fake brick. You don't have to paint it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: Hooray for the Douglases. A baby in a high chair throws a cup.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: Dory! Bad girl! (to the crying four year old) Sally, honey, you don't have to be up yet. Go back to bed. Danny grabs the Cheerios and is almost out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny? No word from St. Copius yet?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (evasive) No, but I'm not so sure about that place anymore. I talked to a guy who went to college there. It's right in the middle of a cornfield. They get eight feet of snow ---

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: It's a fine college and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't know anything, He escapes to the dining room, and without sitting down, the pitcher of milk off the table and pours some on his ‘

dialogues.speaker: MR. NOONAN
dialogues.text: You get out yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: _ (spooning lots of sugar on his cereal} Twice. I caddied for Mr. Webb in the morning and then doubles in the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NOONAN
dialogues.text: How much is that?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Twelve-sixty plus about three bucks in tips.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NOONAN
dialogues.text: Well? Put it in the college fund. Danny sighs, puts down his bowl and goes to a kitchen cup digging into his pocket. Mr. Noonan watches him through t open door. Mrs. Noonan is wiping up spills and feeding th dog at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: Maybe you should call the St. Copius scholarship people. They should've let you know by now. Sally, honey, don't put eggs in your hair.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (pulling bills out of his pocket) I heard there's only two girls there and they're both nuns. This guy had to take a cow to the prom and the cow had to be in carly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: Well, the Mazenak boy went to St. Copious and he had a marvelous time.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: {taking a cookie jar off the shelf} Me's the one who went out with the cow. He stuffs the money into the cookie jar trying to hide it from his father.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NOONAN
dialogues.text: (from the dining room) I saw that! That was about five bucks and change. Danny comes back into the dining room eating his cereal.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I had a couple of burgers and some Pepsis for lunch. He flees toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NOONAN
dialogues.text: How many Pepsis?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (from the kitchen} Four or five.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NOONAN
dialogues.text: What are you -- a diabetic!?

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Hit him, Dad! Get the strap! Danny's a diatetic! Danny dumps his dirty dishes in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NOONAN
dialogues.text: (shouts from the dining room) You're not leaving this house till we settle this college thing.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm just going upstairs for a minute. He dashes out of the kitchen and up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NOONAN
dialogues.text: (o.s. to Mrs. Noonan) I'm telling you, if he hasn't got anything lined up by September, I'm going to ask Tom Burdick to put him on at the lumberyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can hear his parents arguing as he rummages in his clo MRS. NOONAN (0.s.)} He's not going to work in the lumber- yard! Danny grabs a faded windbreaker and a letter drops out of pocket. He reads it with a grim expression.

dialogues.speaker: THE LETTER
dialogues.text: It reads: The St. Copius scholarship foundation regrets t inform you that your application for student aid has been refused, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. NOONAN (0.s.) Well, he's not going to be a caddy all his life, is he?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He folds up the letter and hides it on a shelf. MRS. NOONAN (v.0.) Danny? Devilled ham or tuna? JI can't open both.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: {shouts} How about neither? With the argument continuing downstairs, he goes to the window and jumps out. For a moment we think he's committe suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings nimbly to a downspout, hops to a tree branch, climbs through a weathered treehouse and slides down a rope to the ground. Then he jumps on a Sears ten speed bike and pedals away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny rides down a street lined with houses like his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The houses are bigger, the lawns wider and greener, as Danny crosses over into a more exclusive section of the suburbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Danny is riding past large mansions on rambling estat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny turns down a private driveway flanked by two stone columns. On one column is a brass plaque that reads: Bushwood Country Club. END CREDITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early morning mist rises from the golf course and shafts sunlight slant through the trees as we look at two figure standing on the tee five hundred yards away. One of the figures swings, a click is heard and ball sails into the air. It hangs for a long moment and drops right in the middle of the fairway, two hundred yards from the green. The golfer hands his club to his caddy and starts walking toward the ball. As they approach, we begin to see them more clearly. It i Danny, caddying for TY WEBB, a handsome, thirty-ish bache with clear eyes and an air of relaxed self control. His outfit is all soft flannel and cashmere. Everything about him tells us that he is the perfect golfer.

dialogues.speaker: TY AND DANNY
dialogues.text: They walk along in quiet conversation. Danny tries hard t match Ty's easy, elegant stride.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Mr. Webb, can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: When you were eighteen, do you remember having trouble deciding what you wanted to do with your... uh, you know...life?

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Sure. I didn't know whether to go to West Point, sail my father's ship to the islands or just take a year off skiing in the Alps. why?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Forget it. I don't think you'd understand. Ty Come on. I know what you mean. I had the same problem at eighteen, at twenty-one, twenty-five, twenty-nine and thirty-two ~~ and yesterday. I almost blew my brains out with a silver-plated Beretta. So what's your problem?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What isn't my problem? Did you have to take the Cooter Preference test when you were a senior in high school?

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Yes. It said I should be a firewatcher. What are you supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: An underachiever. {shakes his head) I gotta go to college. I gotta!

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Do you want to go to college?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: In Nebraska? Besides, it costs like eight thousand dollars a year. My Dad can't afford it. And I haven't even told him about the scholarship I didn't get. I'll probably have to work in a lumberyard for the rest of my life.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: What's wrong with lumber. I own two lumberyards.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I notice you don't spend too much time there.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: I don't know where they are. They reach Ty's ball.

dialogues.speaker: THE LAKE
dialogues.text: Ty's ball rests near the edge of a beautiful lake that cuts across the fairway. On the opposite shore is a lovely green flanked by sandtraps.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Okay, Danny. TI think you've suffered enough. First lesson. Did you sce Star Wars? (he takes a silk scarf out of his golf bag) LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh Anum  10

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah --~

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: All right. I'll be Alec Guiness and you be the wimpy kid from the Space farm.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: (blindfolding himself) There's a force in the universe that makes things happen. Al1 you have to do is get in touch with it. He fumbles with the clubs in his bag, feeling for a seven iron. Finally he lifts the blindfold a little and takes the right club. Then he goes to his ball and takes a blindfolded practice swing.

dialogues.speaker: . TY
dialogues.text: Find your center -~- stop thinking -- let it happen -- ‘Be the ball' -- (he swings and hits the ball)

dialogues.speaker: THE BALL
dialogues.text: It sails over the lake, hits high on the green and rolls down to within inches of the hole.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY AND TY
dialogues.text: Danny stands there amazed. Ty starts blindfolding him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (surprised) What?

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Hit one. Try it. Danny peeks to line up the shot, then lowers the blindfol and gets ready to hit.

dialogues.speaker: LNOUNTMLLIGE. CGN
dialogues.text: ir

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: (droning hypnotically) Just relax -- be the ball -- find your center -- turn off all the sound -- picture the shot -- be completely still: --~

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (impatiently) It's a little hard with you talking like that.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Oh! All right -- I'1l shut up -- I'm shutting up now -- I've stepped talking. Danny swings and hits the ball. Ty watches it rise and drop into the lake.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: {taking off the blindfold} Where'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Right in the lumberyard. We'll work on it -- honestly. Just figure out what you really want. Once you know, everything else takes care of itself. They walk off together. A mechanical roar is heard.

dialogues.speaker: A KUGE TRACTOR MOWER
dialogues.text: A huge grasscutter appears suddenly over a rise, it's big plaid blower bags ballooning out from its sides. The GROUNDSKEEPER waves casually to Ty and Danny from his tractor seat as he rumbles past them. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A public transit bus stops across the street from the: ma entrance to the club. The route sign on the front of ‘the bus reads: FROM THE ClTY. The bus pulls away revealing a half dozen teenage CADDIES arriving for work. They cross the street, rollicking and punching at each other. A few Black and Latin Maids and Kitchen Helpers arrive with the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caddies come up the driveway. Leading the group is TONY D'ANNUNZIO, nineteen, a tough-looking, inner-city kid with disco haircut and a cigarette dangling negligent from his lips. With him are his brothers -~ ANGIE, a mild-mannered, dopily smiling seventeen year old and JOEY, fourteen, Bushwood's newest caddy, tough like Tony, but cuter.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: He accosts one of the maids.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey, Maria! The Immigration guy was lookin’ for you yesterday. You know, there's a law if you screw an Italian, you're an automatic citizen. She laughs uncomprehendingly and continues talking in Spanish to her friends, Two other caddies have arrived with the D'’Annunzio’s -- GOOFY, a gawky, bespectacled sixteen year old and MOTORMOUTH, a fast-talking, eighteen year old class clown As they cut across the parking lot, they check out the ca of the club members.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORMOUTH
dialogues.text: {like an announcer) We're here at the Thirteenth Annual Bushwood Auto Show and what a collection of four-wheel fantasies we have here, right Goofy? (raps a stationwagon) ~- Here's a newcomer to this morning's show, Mr. and Mrs. Newburger's 1981 Ford Country Square.

dialogues.speaker: GOOFY
dialogues.text: Breathtakingly beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORMOUTH
dialogues.text: An absolute hog.

dialogues.speaker: A PORSCHE
dialogues.text: A black Porsche Turbo Carrera with prominent "MD" marking races up the access road toward the parking lot. The driv has to slam on his brakes to avoid hitting the D'Annunzio

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED,
dialogues.text: who are deliberately slow getting out of the way. The horn honks frantically. The caddies slowly clear the road as the driver guns his motor. The moment they're clear, he lurches forward to pass them.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: He does a flip off the car as if he's been hit and lands sprawled on the grass.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: {rolling around in mock agony) Yaaaaaaaaaah!

dialogues.speaker: THE PORSCHE
dialogues.text: It screeches to a halt. The tinted window WHIRS down revealing DR. BLAINE BEEPER, a rich, conceited big-city surgeon. He looks back, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BEEPER
dialogues.text: Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: He's on the grass twitching and flopping, the other caddies standing around in horror.

dialogues.speaker: THE PORSCHE
dialogues.text: Beeper grabs his black doctor's bag and leaps from the ca He stops.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: Both Joey and the caddies have disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: BEEPER
dialogues.text: He slams his doctor's bag against a tree trunk in a rage then looks at it realizing what he's done. He gives the b a tentative shake and hears a $6,000 tinkle of broken gla and instruments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several caddies are lounging in the yard in front of the caddyshack -- a one-story white frame building with green tile roof and green shutters. Joey DB'Annunzio practices hook shots against a backboard attached to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: GOOFY
dialogues.text: He's sitting on a bench with RAY, an old, professional ca wearing a dirty golf cap with an emblem from the 1946 Bui Open. His suntanned arms are covered with tatoos. Goffy dunks doughnuts into his coffee as Ray talks.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: I jumped ship in Hong Kong and Inade my way to Tibet where I got on as a looper at this golf club up there in the Himalayan Mountains.

dialogues.speaker: GOOFY
dialogues.text: A looper?

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: A caddie -- a jock! So I tell ‘em I'm a pro, so who do they give me? The Dalai Lama himself ~- flowin' white robes and everything. So I give him his driver and he tees off -- right into this glacier and his ball goes down this 10,000 foot crevice. And you know what the Dalai Lama says?

dialogues.speaker: GOOFY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: ‘shit.’ Yeah -- 'Shit!' And you know what else. I'm full of shit. Yeah. ~~ Goofy stares at him with his mouth full of doughnut.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He crosses the caddyyard. From the way the caddies greet him, we can see that he's both liked and respected. A basketball rolls up to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (shouts) Hey, Noonan! Little help! Danny picks up the ball, closes his eyes and takes a hook shot at the basket.

dialogues.speaker: THE BASKET
dialogues.text: The ball sails high over the backboard and onto the roof of the caddyshack.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: He glares at Danny.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot, wipehole! Danny goes into the caddyshack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More caddies are lounging on benches, playing cards, etc. Danny enters and goes to the window of the caddymaster's office. Tony D'’Annunzio is in the office.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (holding up a ticket) Hiya, Tony. Where's Lou?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: He went to the Pro Shop for a minute, You wanna take over till he gets back?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Where you goin'? Angie, Tony's rat-like brother, appears.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: Noonan, you wanna buy some clock radios?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nah ---

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: Got any friends who want clock radios? .

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: How many you got?

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: How many you need? Angie walks away laughing.

dialogues.speaker: A BENCH
dialogues.text: INJUN JOE, a big silent Indian of indeterminate age is pl a game with FEEB, a twitching adult caddy with just a hin mental deficiency. They take turns bowling at wooden tees a golf ball, betting on each roll.

dialogues.speaker: FEEB
dialogues.text: (to Injun Joe) Do you have a dime for ten pennies?

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: {making fun of him) Hey, Feeb! What do you want a dime for when you got ten pennies? Ten is more than one.

dialogues.speaker: FEEB
dialogues.text: Pennies only work in the gumball machine. I want M & M's.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (joining Angie) Here, Feeb. I'11 give it to you. Feeb holds out the pennies to Joey who slaps his hand, scattering them all over the caddyshack.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He turns to look and sees the little D'Annunzio's botheri Feeb.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: {to Tony) Your brothers are animals. (shouts at them) cut it out, moron!

dialogues.speaker: FEEB
dialogues.text: He's on his knees looking for his pennies.

dialogues.speaker: INJUN JOE
dialogues.text: Here, Feeb. Here’s a dime.

dialogues.speaker: FEEB
dialogues.text: Thank you, Injun Joe. He gets off his knees, but Angie snatches his cap and tos it to Joey.

dialogues.speaker: FEEB
dialogues.text: (calls plaintively) Dan -- ny -- They got my hat again.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (steps in) Give it back to him, Joey.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: Here. (he tosses it back to his brother} Angie! Danny turns to Angie.

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: You want it, Noonan? Take it. Danny grabs for him but Joey jumps on his back and they g knocking over a gumball machine which breaks and sends gu rolling all over the place. Then Angie jumps on Danny to Joey, but Tony arrives and yanks Angie to his feet, cuffi sharply a couple of times. Danny gets a good grip on Litt Joey's neck and pastes him to the wall. Younger caddies scurry around after the pennies and gumba Injun Joe laughs.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: LOU LOOMIS, the Caddymaster, enters. He's a likable maste sergeant type with a veneer of toughness to keep the cadd in line. Lou (over the noise) Okay, break it up! Pipe down! All of you! Angie takes on last wild swing at Danny but accidentally Lou on the arm. The caddies go suddenly quiet. Lou grabs and pushes him over to a sign on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: What™s the sign say?

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: No fighting.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: What's it mean?

dialogues.speaker: ANGIE
dialogues.text: No fighting.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: You owe me one gumball machine. Now clean up that mess, (Angie starts to protest) Now! {turning to Danny and Tony) What is this? I count on you guys to keep these monkeys in line. (squinting at Joey) What's that candy wrapper doing there? (Joey looks down) Don't you see it? Well, pick it up! Joey picks it up. Lou addresses all the caddies.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: {turning to cowed caddics) Now, I'm not going to have any trouble from you guys this summer-. I'll put it right on the line -- there's been a lot of complaints already -- fooling around on the course. Bad language. Smoking grass. Poor caddying. (the caddies hang their heads in mock shame) So if you want to get fired, just keep it up. Somebody belches. Lou turns to Jocy, hands him a kleenex for his blecdy nose.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: And another thing. If any of you are thinking of going to college-- Noonan, you may want to listen to this -- Carl Lipbaum died last week in summer school from a severe anxiety attack. The caddies mutter in surprise and sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: GOOFY
dialogues.text: I heard he swallowed his vomit during a test.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  19

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: However it happened, he was a good eaddy and a good kid.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: He was a brown nose, Lou. You hated him.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Anyway, that means the caddy scholar- ship is available -- and anyone who wants it should go see Judge Smails.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORMOUTH
dialogues.text: And kiss his ass.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: That would help. Now let's go. We got golfers waiting. The caddies start to file out the door.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: You, Joey! Pick up that blcod.

dialogues.speaker: INT, MEN'S LOCKER ROOM
dialogues.text: A cloud of steam billows from the steam room as the door opens. Several portly members can be seen through the mis They lock like ancient Roman senators wrapped in their sh and towels. Several other members stand or sit around the locker room, playing cards or changing in and out of golf and tennis togs.

dialogues.speaker: JUBGE SMALLS
dialogues.text: A rich old fart and presiding head of Bushwood holds out pair of golf shoes to SMOKE, the black locker room attend

dialogues.speaker: SMALLS
dialogues.text: (irritably) Oh, Westinghouse! Look at the built-up wax on these shoes. This is quality leather. I want the wax stripped, and I want them creamed and buffed with a soft chamois, and I want them now. Chopchop. —

dialogues.speaker: SMOKE
dialogues.text: Yes, your Honor. Smoke applies one shoe to an electric buffer.

dialogues.speaker: BEEPER
dialogues.text: (on the phone) We're just about to tee off now so move all my appointments back a half hour. Testing now: (he unhooks an electronic beeper from his belt) Three, two, one, test. (his beeper goes off) Check.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: He's now in the middle of a joke.

dialogues.speaker: SMATLS
dialogues.text: (bad Jewish accent) »..and then we eat and eat, and screw and screw until we drop from exhaustion. lUvery day! A fat OLD CRONY begins to giggle.

dialogues.speaker: SMATLS
dialogues.text: {continuing} »+-and Solly says, ‘Moe! Moc! Heaven sounds wonderful! and the other Jewish fellow says ---

dialogues.speaker: TY WEBB
dialogues.text: He's sitting behind another row of lockers listening to t joke as he ties his shoes, SMAILS {v.0.) Heaven? What do you mean heaven?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SMAILS
dialogues.text: He rises to the punchline, but Ty beats him to it. TY (v.o.) (shouts, interrupting) -+-I'm a bull in Montana! Smails winces and looks sharply at Ty, who appears from the lockers.

dialogues.speaker: AN OLD CRONY
dialogues.text: His pudgy The CRONY pink face jiggles as he laughs.

dialogues.speaker: OLD CRONY
dialogues.text: You have to hang it to the Jews -- they know how funny they are.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER MEMBER
dialogues.text: You're not suggesting we change our membership policy. puts on a Bishop's collar and closes his locker.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: Oh, no. They have many fine clubs of their own.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: (icily) Oh, hello Webb. What'd you shoot today?

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: I don't keep score, your Honor. Ty heads for the exit and stops, blocked by Beeper's stretched-out phone cord.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Beep-beep. Beeper jumps and Ty exits.

dialogues.speaker: SMATLS
dialogues.text: (shakes head contemptucusly) That fellow's got a real chip on his shoulder too bad for his father. (changing mood) Say, Bishop, did you hear the one about the little colored boy who --- He frowns and presses the Judge's golf shoe against the buffing wheel until the shoe begins to smoke and sparks shoot out. Then he looks at the shoc and smiles at the big burned patch on the toe.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: The caddies troop up. the path to the first tee area.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MOTORMOUTH (v.o0.) Well, it’s a lovely day for looping here at the beautiful Bushwood Country Club.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORMOUTH
dialogues.text: He holds a candy bar like a hand mike. Goofy and Danny walk alongside.

dialogues.speaker: MOTORMOUTH
dialogues.text: We've got about twenty-five loopers all primed and ready to be assigned their prospective loops by Looper Leader Lou Loomis. And gee, they're an excited bunch of caddies -- all pumped up to hump those fifty pound bags about five miles. Right, Danny?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That's right, Mouth. It's a grueling test of strength and ignorance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny approaches the practice tee and sees SAM RIVIERA, t club's golf pro, finishing a lesson with MR. & MRS. HAVER Sam is about forty, deeply tanned and dressed in pastel g sweater and slacks. The Havercamps are a cheerfully senil old couple, dressed in matching outfits, who keep gamely trying to hit their practice shots. They succeed only in gouging deep holes around their golf balls as they repeat swing and miss.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He watches with weary patience as the Havercamps ineptly away.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Havercamp, try looking . at the ball this time. Mrs. Havercamp, you've got your clubface turned around again. The old man swings and gouges a huge divot.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HAVERCAMP
dialogues.text: (she giggles, swings and hits a short dribbler) Whee!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Danny picks up their matching baby-blue golf bags and app the Havercamps.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Morning, Mr. Havercamp, Mrs. Havercamp. I'm Danny. You're next up.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HAVERCAMP
dialogues.text: Let's go, Dolly. I'm hot today.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIRST TEE
dialogues.text: MRS. HAVERCAMP is about to drive.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HAVERCAMP
dialogues.text: (winding up) Ready for blast-off! Whee! She tops the ball and it rolls thirty feet down the fairw

dialogues.speaker: MR. HAVERCAMP
dialogues.text: (applauding) That was a peach, hon!

dialogues.speaker: SAM RIVIERA
dialogues.text: He stands next to Danny watching Mr. Havercamp.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (shouting encouragement) Excellent! (to Danny) Good luck, Noonan. This could be the longest eighteen holes ever played.

dialogues.speaker: THE SNACK SHOP
dialogues.text: Several tables are filled with members having sandwiches and beer.

dialogues.speaker: THE COUNTER
dialogues.text: MAGGIE, a very cute, rosy~checked Irish girl in her early twenties. When her last customer exits, she turns to the frozen custard machine, takes the bigger size sugar cone and dispenses for hersclf an incredibly tall, very precar Softee Freeze. She takes a happy lick and spots Danny com off the ninth,

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He trudges up to the Snack Shop completely exhausted, his shirt soaked with sweat. Maggie smiles and signals covert to him. Danny slips around to the back of the Snack Shop.

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK DOOR
dialogues.text: Maggie comes out and gives him a free burger and a shake.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hi, Maggic.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Hi. Don't let the Judge see you. (Danny tries to steal a kiss but she ducks it) Not here. (she hands him a pair of boys underpants) You left these last night when you ran off.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (embraces her) I had to babysit. You want to go out again tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Out to my room? Look, Danny, I like you a lot, but let's not make a regular thing out of it. We've got a good friendship going and I'd like to keep it that way. Besides, I got some bad news today.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (nibbles her ear} What?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: {hugs him tightly) They won't renew my work permit. I have to go back to Ireland at the end of the summer.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Gee, that's a drag, Mag.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  25

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I really want to stay. (hinting cheerfully) If I were married to an American, I could.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: {laughs) No problem. You could live in my roam ~- under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to college?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Doesn't look like it -- unless I get the caddy scholarship.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: You'll get it. {teasing} And we'll get married -~ just for show, of course -- and I'll be a stewardess for Aer Lingus and be flyin' all over the place. Now doesn't that sound like something?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: He comes around the corner of the Snack Shop.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Aer Lingus? I know her sister -- Connie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (laughing) You've got a smart mouth.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: That's what Connie told me. Danny sees Mr. Havercamp looking around for him.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: {rushing off) I gotta go!

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: {calls out) Come by later!

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hey, Maggie. The Immigration guy was lookin' for you yesterday ---

dialogues.speaker: THE FAIRWAY
dialogues.text: SANDY MacFIDDISH, Bushwood's Scottish greenskecpcr, is standing by his electric utility cart with his tartan tam in his hands, taking orders from Judge Smails.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: (irate) Do you know what moles can do to a golf course?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: They must be tunnclin’ in from that construction site across the road.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: I don't care where they're coming from. JI want every last mole extermianted or Bushwood will start looking for a new greens- keeper. Is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: Very clear, sir.

dialogues.speaker: A MOLE
dialogues.text: It pops its head out of a hole and cocks its head. Then i hears a noise and ducks back in.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: He drags a thick water hose onto the fairway and sticks t nozzle into the mole hole.

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTEENTH GREEN
dialogues.text: Danny comes off the course really exhausted now, followed by the Havercamps, indomitable despite having played the worst round of golf imaginable.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (handing them their scorecards) I get 188 for you, sir, and 202 for your wife.

dialogues.speaker: MR TAVERCAMP
dialogues.text: Hold on a minute, son. I get 186 for me. Well, let's not make a ~ federal case out of it. This is for you -- and thanks. (hands him a tip) LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  27

dialogues.speaker: DANNY'S HAND
dialogues.text: holding two shiny quarters. DANNY (v.0.) (disappointed) Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He trots wearily across a fairway lugging both golf bags. He trips over Sandy's water hose and falls flat on his fa The clubs spill out of the bags with a noisy clatter and two dozen golf balls go rolling off in all directions.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (totally exasperated) God damn son of a bitch! His anger is cut short as he spots someone walking toward

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Danny sees LACEY UNDERALL, a very beautiful girl, walking toward him in a short, very alluring tennis skirt. She has slim, shapely legs, long, golden hair, a great tan an a cover-girl complexion. She's carrying a tennis racquet and with one smooth move, she benés slightly and scoops up one of the golf balls that rolled away from Danny.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: {tossing the golf ball to Danny) Walk much?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (stuffing the clubs back into the bags) Oh, no. I just -- I was just resting. She smiles and walks away with a toss of her curls. Her walk is both sexy and athletic. She absently brushes a fly off the back of her thigh with her racquet.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He gapes at her and suddenly water comes shooting up out a dozen moleholes, falling like rain on Danny.

dialogues.speaker: THE HAVERCAMPS
dialogues.text: fhey stand looking up at the sky, getting completely dren

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tennis courts are hidden behind dense bushes but the pock~pock of balls being hit can be heard as Danny saunte by. He nods casually to a pair of golfers as they pass, then as soon as they're gone, Danny ducks into the bushes

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: We can hear the sound of youthful laughter as Danny peers through the hurricane fence at the tennis courts.

dialogues.speaker: THE TENNIS COURTS
dialogues.text: Lacey is playing with three young club MEMBERS. Her partn is SPAULDING SMAILS, a pudgy, truculent-looking seventeen old -- Judge Smails' spoiled grandson. Lacey hits a nice backhand, then waits for there turn, bu Spaulding insists on taking the next shot.

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: I got it! It's mine! Lacey backs off relucantly and watches Spaulding hit a lame forehand right into the net.

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: Shit! (blaming Lacey) Will you stay out of my way! He flings his racquet in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Christ, Spaulding! I hope you screw better than you play tennis.

dialogues.speaker: THETR OPPONENTS
dialogues.text: NOBLE NOYES, a tomboyish girl with fuzzy red hair walks u to the net.

dialogues.speaker: NOBLE
dialogues.text: Hey, Lacey, are you coming to the dinner dance tonight?

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Will it be any good?

dialogues.speaker: NOBLE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: (walking back to the base line to serve) You talked me into it.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUSHES
dialogues.text: The TENNIS PRO, a middle-aged, red-faced man wearing whit and a floppy tennis hat, walks by and sees Danny's ass sticking out of the bushes. Ue puts down the basket of practice balls he's carrying, winds up to swing with his racquet, and swats Danny hard on the backside. INT’. CLUB KITCHEN Danny comes flying through the door into a maelstrom of activity. It's all banging pots, and sizzling stoves with food and people flying everywhere. He's in a white jacket carrying a big tray of dirty dishes.

dialogues.speaker: THE COOK
dialogues.text: CHARLIE, the Hungarian cook is screaming at everyone as h carves a big roast with a huge butcher knife.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (pounding the knife) This! This! (chops a sponge in half) That! That! (waves his arms and the knife goes flying out of his hand)

dialogues.speaker: A BUSBOY
dialogues.text: The huge knife sticks in the wall just in front of his fa He drops two racks full of glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She snags Danny and pulls him through the swinging doors.

dialogues.speaker: CLUB DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: Danny and Maggie bustle over to a service area and start loading trays with ice water, rolls and butter. Danny locks around the room and spots Lacey.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY UNDERALL
dialogues.text: She's sitting at a table with Judge Smails, his wife MRS. SMAILS, a Wagnerian dowager, Spaulding Smails, the Judge's loathsome grandson, Dr. Beeper and his wife, CONN BEEPER who is obviously much too charming and attractive to be married to a creep like Dr. Beeper. Lacey looks great in an off-the-shoulder white cotton dre Judge Smails is handling the introductions when Danny and Maggie arrive with the bread and butter.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SMAILS
dialogues.text: {clasping Lacey's luscious shoulder} Lacey Underali, certainly you remember Dr. and Constance Beeper from Hope Sound last winter. Lacey's mother has sent us her daughter for the summer. I think she's being saved for a real debutante ball.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BEEPER
dialogues.text: {lecring obnoxiously) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE BEEPER
dialogues.text: We did meet. You wore that wonderful g-string bathing suit at the béach. The doctor here almost had a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BEEPER
dialogues.text: That's not funny, Connie.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE BEEPER
dialogues.text: What brings you to. this backwater anyway?

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Uh -- Daddy wanted to broaden me.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE BEEPER
dialogues.text: Here? Good luck, doll.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMAILS
dialogues.text: I think our community has a lot to offer, Connie -- really. Danny has worked his way around to Lacey and is loading u her plate with butter -- about a pound of it.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: (noticing) I think I have enough butter now.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry. (backs off) If you need anything --- Maggic drags him away.

dialogues.speaker: THE BUSSING STATION
dialogues.text: Danny and Maggie arrange bowls of salad on their trays.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (burned) Is that why you showed up tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Lacey Underall. She's the biggest whore in Philadelphia...It's all over the club. Panny looks at Lacey with even greater interest. The NOIS of a glass breaking startles him.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER TABLE
dialogues.text: In contrast to the Smails' table, these guests are having rollicking good time. It's the FUN COUPLES: SCOTT, GATSBY and their foxy, tipsy wives, SUKI and WALLY. They are hos a new face at Bushwood, AL CZERNAK, a stocky, balding, ce block in a flaming leisure suit. His voice is loud, his Manner is deliberately offensive and he seems to really e the company of these rich, young marrieds. Danny arrives to clean up the broken glass.

dialogues.speaker: AL CZERNAK
dialogues.text: «..So when Mona died suddenly last winter, I said to myself, 'Al, if you keep bustin' your hump sixteen, twenty hours a day, you're gonna wind up with a sixty million buck funeral for yourself.' He farts loudly; Danny can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: AL CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Sorry -~ somebody step on a duck? The Fun Couples laugh.

dialogues.speaker: AL CZERNAK
dialogues.text: So I -- (catches Maggie's eye, grabbing her skirt) Hey, doll, could you scare up another round for our table -- and tell the cook this is low-grade dog food, okay? And happy birthday. He slips a twenty into Maggie's hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (delighted) Oh! Thank you. (exits)

dialogues.speaker: AL CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (to Pun Couples) Gad, I've had better food at the ballgame. The Fun Couples break up again. Danny stares at Al, enjoy his outrageous antics.

dialogues.speaker: AL CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Anyway, sO now I just keep to real estate -~ I mean with the market these days, if you own anything but dirt, you own a popcorn fart. {notices Danny laughing behind him, slips him $5) Hey, junior, ask our waitress if she wants to get married.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS' TABLE
dialogues.text: The stiffs all stare at Czernak. Only Connie is amused. Lacey is just bored.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Al notices Judge Smails staring coldly at him from the next table.

dialogues.speaker: AL CZFRNKA
dialogues.text: Ney, who's the mummy? (waves) Hiya. He pretends to blow his nose in his loud tie; Smails' jaw

dialogues.speaker: THE HUNGARIAN COOK, (CHARLIE)
dialogues.text: He screams, wide-eyed, into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dog food?!! He grabs his cleaver and heads for the door. Two assistan tackle the enraged alien, knocking over a tower of freshl washed pots, causing a tremendous din.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Al Czernak's table bursts into loud applause at the crash and continued commotion behind the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Danny bobbles a dish of ice cream at the sound of the tremendous crash in the kitchen and spills a few drops of hot fudge on Lacey's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Ow! That's hot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of drops of hot chocolate sauce run down Lacey's bare shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He stares, open-mouthed, reaches into his pocket, pulls o the underpants Maggie gave him earlicr, and starts wiping Lacey's shoulder with them.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: She stares at the underpants, then at Danny. Danny beats it. A band starts playing in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Members and guests drift into the wood-panelled lounge an ballroom area. A very boring, six~piece COMBO is playing a bad Beatle tune at half-speed.

dialogues.speaker: THE FUN COUPLES
dialogues.text: They stop at the edge of the the dance floor with Al Czer watching the club members as they dance sedately.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (loud) Yike -- Dance of the Living Dead! The dancing COUPLES steer clear of Czernak, afraid to get too close to his pink leisure wear.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR
dialogues.text: Handsome, slick Tony D'Annunzio is moonlighting asa bartender. He makes an elaborate show of mixing drinks while he talks a mildly sarcastic stream of patter to the slightly deaf and nearly senile Havercamps.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So how was dinner, huh? You each get a special bowl of mush? (pouring their drinks) Here you go -- two special extra- flat Shirley Temples straight up yours. To your health. Danny enters lugging a bin of ice.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: {to Danny) Noonan! Did you see her, man?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Ber! The new one.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: She stands against the wall listening to Dr. Beeper as he fawns all over her. TONY {v.o.) Twinkle-tits. Slurp-slurp.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR
dialogues.text: Danny is staring at Lacey again.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: She's the biggest whore on the East Coast. Danny looks at her with even greater intcrest. Two young PRE-DEBS come up to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST GIRL
dialogues.text: I'd like a G&T, please.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND GIRL
dialogues.text: Make it two.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: What? Two T&A's? You want to give me two T&A's -- good. Let's have a drink first, okay? Then I'll show you where the shark bit me. The girls giggle as Tony mixes their drinks. One of them smiles coyly at Danny. He smiles back politely, but keeps watching Lacey.

dialogues.speaker: TY WEBB
dialogues.text: He wanders into the ballroom looking very suave in his hand-tailored evening wear. He lights a cigarette and leans against the wall as he surveys the action in the ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: FUN COUPLES
dialogues.text: Czernak and Suki are dancing on the fringe of the dance floor, trying to make the most of a very dull situation. Suki spots Ty and dances Czernak over to Wally.

dialogues.speaker: SUKI
dialogues.text: Hunky guy alert!

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: He waves at the Fun Couples, glad to see some people he likes, and joins them.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: (hugging Ty} Hiya, beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: (clapping him on the back) Hunka~hunka.

dialogues.speaker: SUKI
dialogues.text: Meet somebody, Ty. (turning to Czernak) Ty Webb, this is Al Czernak. (to Ty) Al built our condo in Palm Beach.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Really? You also built a new shopping mall in the middle of a bird sanctuary last year,. didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: AL
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah, and it wasn't easy, either. The Audubon Society put me on their hit list. I was getting obscene phone calls from Marlin Perkins. We had to relocate every godamn last grouse, crow and chickadee to a kids' aviary next to the Woolco. You should see it.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: (ruefully) T have.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: {laughs) It's a regular birdshit factory.

dialogues.speaker: SUKI
dialogues.text: (nudging Ty) Heads up. I think somebody's giving you the big eye.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: She gazes steadily at Ty over the top of her cocktail gla

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: He looks back at her without wavering.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: The best piece in town is my guess.

dialogues.speaker: GATSBY
dialogues.text: No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't believe it. She's coming over here.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He stands at the kitchen door holding a tray of little ca and pastries, watching Lacey as she crosses the room towa Ty Webb. Suddenly Maggie bursts through the door, banging it hard into Danny's back and sending the pastries flying the tray. They both stoop to pick up the cakes and pastri

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: He watches Lacey as she comes up to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Hello. My name is Lacey Underall. I'm seventeen and I'm trouble. Ty is amused and intrigued by her boldness. Ty Ty Webb. I bet you're not as bad as your reputation.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: (provocative) Better. Will you dance with me?

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Sure. She takes his hand and leads him to the dance floor. The Fun Couples make a big show of raising their eyebrows and elbowing each other in the background.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR
dialogues.text: Tony is still hustling the two Pre-Debs.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So what you girls gonna do when you grow up, huh? Drop acid in France not even wearing no tops probably, an' then you burn out and marry some suit who's into squash. I bet you're still into the Captain and Tenille. “(the girls Laugh) Let's face it, girls, it's bigger than both of you, if you know what I mean. Czernak steps up to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: {to Tony) Pal, can you make a Bullshot?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Can you make a shoe smell? He starts to mix the drink. Czernak peels some bills off his huge wad and tosses them on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Funny. Here, treat yourself to a real haircut.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Thanks!

dialogues.speaker: THF DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Lacey is coming on to Ty as they dance, but he manages to keep a little distance between them.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Well, Ty, what do you do for excitement around here?

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: I play a lot of golf.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Golf? Jesus, Nixon plays golf. I bet you've got a lot of inter- esting storics about your ball landing in the road.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: What do you do, then?

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Oh, I enjoy skinny~-skiing, going to bullifights on acid...hey, I bet you've got a lot of nice ties.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Would you like to tie me up with some of your ties, Ty?

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Hey, I got an idea, let's pretend we're human beings.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: He crosses the dance floor greeting and goosing people on his way to the bandstand.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE AND MRS. SMATLS
dialogues.text: They're doing an arthritic fox trot near the bandstand. Czernak bumps into them and lifts his glass in a friendly toast, spilling half his drink on the floor. Mrs. Smails glares at him as Czernak mounts the bandstand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMAILS
dialogues.text: (to the Judge) Who is that disgusting man?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SMAILS
dialogues.text: (scowling) I think he's a guest of the Scotts.

dialogues.speaker: THE BANDSTAND
dialogues.text: Czernak taps the BANDLEADER on the shoulder. He's an agin Don Ameche look-a-like in a very crummy tuxcdo.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (slipping him some bills) Listen, Ramon, there's another Jackson in it for you if you can goose the old thermostat a little. The Bandleader abruptly cuts off the band in the middle o a number.

dialogues.speaker: BANDLEADER
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, number forty, please. Czernak showers the band with bills.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: And make it hot!

dialogues.speaker: THE DANCK FI.OOR
dialogues.text: The band starts blaring out a noisy disco number. Most of the older couples leave the floor immediately, but a few try to keep up with the kids who are starting to boogie. The Fun Couples are doing a wild, drunken Salsa. Judge and Mrs. Smails stand on the sidelines glowering at the Fun Couples. Czernak dances up to them and grabs Mrs. Smails' hand.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (to the Judge) Hey, give somebody else a chance, you lucky devil. He drags the reluctant matron onto the dance floor and propels her through a goofy John Travolta imitation.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (cheek to cheek with Mrs. Smails) Oh, baby! You must've been something before clectricity.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEEPERS
dialogues.text: Connie is laughing at Czernak's crazy flcorshow. Judge Smails comes storming up to them holding his wife's coat.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  41

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (to Doctor) Find out who invited that man -- and tell them never to do it again.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: He goes out onto the dance floor and pries Mrs. Smails aw from Czernak.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: (to Czernak} You're no gentleman!

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (dancing away) I'm no doorknob, either?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He's watching Ty talking to Lacey at a table in the corne Tony grabs him and starts walking him to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Cover for me, Noonan. I gotta go out for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: THE TWO PRE-DEBS
dialogues.text: They stand waiting for Tony at the doors to the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR
dialogues.text: Danny goes behind the bar and finds the Bishop waiting fo a drink.

dialogues.speaker: THE BISHOP
dialogues.text: Another Rob Roy, m'boy. Danny is so intent on Lacey that he starts ineptly improv a drink for the Bishop -- Grenadine, Tequila and Slivowit

dialogues.speaker: TY AND LACEY
dialogues.text: They stroll out of the ballroom arm in arm.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He tosses the bar rag into the punch bowl and leaves. The Bishop takes a sip of his drink, gags and spits it ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An explosion of sound rises, and a ball sails upward.

dialogues.speaker: A FLAGSTICK
dialogues.text: The ball hits the flag and almost drops in.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: He straightens and marvels at his shot.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Wow! I am the best! Did you see that? Danny backs into frame raking the trap as Ty steps out.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (sullen) No. Danny throws the rake and it bounces, almost hitting Ty.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: What's the matter? You getting lazy? .

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (hearing Lacey) No -- you getting her?

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: {not getting the pun) Pardon me? What are we talking about? Did you ever get that college thing settled?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I've got one more chance -- maybe I can win the caddy scholarship if I suck up to Judge Smails.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: (taking putter from bag) Okay, second lesson -- first, forget everything I told you last time. Ty drops some balls on the green. He turns to Danny and backhand putts perfectly, into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Never rush your swing, stay loose, don't press. Ty casually taps two balls at once. into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: If you obsess on your desire you may clutch at the end like Snec@ in the 79 Masters.... Ty casually kicks a ball right to the edge of the holc.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Missed. Ty Lines up another ball between his legs.

dialogues.speaker: PY
dialogues.text: In one model of the physical universe the shortest distance from one star to another can be in the opposite direction. Ty taps the ball and it hops over the kicked ball and int the cup. Danny blinks.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: {continuing} Basho the Zen Master once wrote, ‘a flute without holes is not a flute; a doughnut without a hole is a danish.' Ty sinks a ball shooting between his legs. He falls to hi hands and knees to line up his last ball.

dialogues.speaker: TY
dialogues.text: Tf you need something from some- one, you should never appear to need it. — (looks up at Danny) Don't move, Grasshopper.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  44

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ty (Cont'd) (he uses the club like a pool cuc, bouncing the ball eff Danny's shoe) If you want to get what you want, you have to stop wanting it first. The ball heads right for the hole and drops. Danny can't believe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big yellow Cadillac convertible roars up to the clubhou entrance and lurches to a halt. The liccnse*plates read "“CZERNAK". Al Czernak gets out wearing a fluorescent pink shirt, ora slacks and red and white, two-tone shoes. A little Japane businessman, MR. YAMAMOTO, gets out the other side dresse in a business suit.

dialogues.speaker: THE PRO SHOP
dialogues.text: Sam Riviera, the club pro is behind the counter waiting o Judge Smails and his grandson, Spaulding.

dialogues.speaker: SMATLS
dialogues.text: Sam, Spaulding needs some balis. (he looks in the display case) How much is that new Vulcan D-10 with the high compression center? Sam reaches into the display case and takes out a ball th comes in its own velvet pouch.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Three dollars cach, your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (hiding his surprise) Uh-huh. And how much are these? He reaches into a goldfish bowl full of used balls.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: They're forty cents each, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SMAILS
dialogues.text: (selecting some balls} That's more like it.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Ah, Judge, that's a Queen Royal.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: It's a ladies ball! Judge Smails drops it quickly and selects another.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: This Ram-2 looks all right.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: Czernak comes barging in followed by Yamamoto.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: He beckons to Sam's ASSISTANT, a twenty year old college

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Hey, kid! I'm Al Czernak -- I'm playing with Drew Scott today and this is my guest, Mr. Yamamoto. You can give me a half dozen of those Vulcan D-10's with the whole shmeer -- clubs, bag, shoes, glove, pants, shirt ~~ (to Yamamoto} You want one of those things that tell you how far you walked? Mr. Yamamoto nods uncomprehendingly.

dialogues.speaker: SAM RIVIERA
dialogues.text: His eyes light up when he hears Czernak's order, and he practically runs over to Czernak, leaving the Judge alone

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: (very solicitious) Sorry, Mr. Czech! I didn't see you come in, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: {wandering around) Hey! Orange balls! Gimme a coupla those -- and a box of those naked lady tees -- and one of those, and that -- stop me! I'm a nut. (picking up a hat) Oh! This is the worst looking hat I ever saw.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  46

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He tries it om and turns to see Smails wearing the same h

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Ooops! Looks good on you, though -- seriously. Smails stalks out of the Pro Shop with Spaulding right be him.

dialogues.speaker: A GOLF BALL
dialogues.text: The word "DAMAGED" is stamped on the ball in big red lett A putter taps the ball out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: PRACTICE GREEN
dialogues.text: Spaulding Smails, the Judge's grandson, is practicing put cursing every time he misses. Motormouth and Goofy stop t

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: Dammit!

dialogues.speaker: THE STARTING BOARD
dialogues.text: Lou, the caddymaster, is chalking the names of the player board near the first tee. The caddies are waiting for the assignments. Danny looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Okay, Smails, Smails, Beeper and Bishop Pickering. Who wants it? The caddies hoot derisively.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (a little embarrassed) Uh -- I'll take Smails if no one's got him.

dialogues.speaker: THE CADDIES
dialogues.text: (sing-song) Brown-nose, brown-nose. Danny gives them the finger as he goes off to caddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caddies are lazing around the fringes of the first te watching the Smails team greet Beeper and the Bishop. the golf shirt has a small white cross where the alligator sh

dialogues.speaker: MOTORMOUTH
dialogues.text: Well, it's quite a moment when two gruesome twosomes like the Beep and the Bish tee off against the Smails Experience, right, Tony?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Looks like Noonan's up to his neck in boogers.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Spaulding takes his driver from his golf bag, which is on two-wheel golf cart, and tees up his ball.

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: He swings and misses. His ball drops off the tee.

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: Turds! (teeing up the ball again) That was practice.

dialogues.speaker: SMATLS
dialogues.text: Spaulding! How many times have T spoken to you about your language!

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: Sorry, Grandpa. I forgot. He swings again.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY AND GOOFY
dialogues.text: Their eyes move to follow the flight of the ball, but qui return to the tee with the ball sitting on it. SPAULDING (v.o.) Double-turds!

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: Spaulding! Goofy starts to crack up, but Danny stifles his own laugh and turns around to hide his smile.

dialogues.speaker: AL CZERNAK
dialogues.text: He comes up the little hill to the first tee talking at t top of his lungs. Yamamoto tags along in a bizarrely un- coordinated golf outfit with price tags still attached to everything.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: So where do we tee off? (sees Scott and Gatsby and waves) Fellahs! {secs the Smails' party) We waiting for these guys? Hey, Smells! Nice hat! Smails tees up his ball.

dialogues.speaker: SMALLS ,
dialogues.text: Bo you mind? I'm about to tee off.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: I bet you slice into the woods. (holds up a bill) Hundred bucks.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: THE CADDIES watch the confrontation with rapt delight. SMAILS turns to Czernak, really indignant.

dialogues.speaker: SMALLS
dialogues.text: Gambling is illegal at Bushwood, sir. And I never slice.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (winking) Oh, yeah, sure. Smails snorts and tees off, slicing it right into the woo THE CADDIES are practically rolling on the grass, trying to laugh out loud. CZERNAK puts the bill away.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Okay, you can owe me.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: I owe you nothing! He shakes his head and stomps off down the fairway after of his foursome, Danny and Goofy shoulder the bags and fo Spaulding trails after, pulling his two-wheel golf cart.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE FIRST TEE
dialogues.text: Lou announces the next foursome.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: (checking them off the start board) Scott, Gatsby, and guests. (to the caddies) Joey, get the big mouth -- Grace, take the little guy -- Tony, you got Scott and Gatsby.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: He walks along the bag rack, looking at each one until he comes to a huge super deluxe model, fully twice as large any normal golf bag. "CZERNAK" is stencilled on it in hug letters. Tiny Joey is dwarfed by it as he drags it out of the rack,

dialogues.speaker: THE FIRST TEE
dialogues.text: Grace, the six-foot girl caddy, walks up to Yamamoto with his bag. All his equipment still has price tags on it, to She looks down at him, he looks up at her towering pulchr and they both giggle amiably. JOEY crosses to the tee, hobbling under the weight of Cze incredible bag as the caddies cheer and jeer at him.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (ta Czernak) You want your driver?

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: No, tell him to pick me up later. Hah! No, yeah, gimme it. Al pulls the club out, removes its boxing glove cover and it to Joey. Then he tees up his ball.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (to Scott and Gatsby) I'm new at this game so you'll have to go easy -- say, ten cents a hole?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (addressing the ball) én' Mr, Moto and me'll have a little side bet. (to Yamamoto) A ten thousand dollar Nassau with optional press and a one hundred Bingo~Bango ~~ no, Bango, hai?

dialogues.speaker: MR. YAMAMOTO
dialogues.text: (more interested in Grace) Hai.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROUGH
dialogues.text: Smails finds his ball, looks around, and tosses it back o the fairway.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: (to Danny) Don't count that. I was interfered with.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  50

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: (lining up his next shot) By the way, what did Mr. Webb shoot this morning?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He doesn't keep score, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: I know, but just guess -- eighty? Seventy-five?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: More like sixty-eight, I think.

dialogues.speaker: SMATLS
dialogues.text: {really jealous) Bah! I don't believe it!

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: He drives off the first tee with no technique but with amazing power.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: He's just about to swing when Czernak's ball bounds into frame and strikes him in the chest. He falls over.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNARK
dialogues.text: He waves apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (bellows) Fore! His foursome starts walking down the fairway. Joe struggl to keep ahead of them, his whole body hidden by the enorm golf bag.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (turning around) Wha'd'ya got in here, anyway -- rocks?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  51

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Come on, when I was your age, IL used to lug fifty pounds of ice up five, six fliphts of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: JOEY
dialogues.text: (unimpressed) So what?

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: So let's dance. He reaches over and switches on a radio built into his go bag. A LOUD disco tune BOOMS out over the course.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SMAILS
dialogues.text: He's just about to hit when the loud music comes wafting the course.

dialogues.speaker: SMATLS
dialogues.text: Now what in heaven? {he turns and shakes his fist at Czernak in the distance) That man is a menace. (shouts) Turn that off! (Czernak waves back) Gad! The Judge hits a bag shot and stomps off after it. Danny walks alongside, taking his club.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: That music is a violation of my personal privacy. He's breaking the law.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Really? I've always been very fascinated with the Law.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: Oh? What areas?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: All areas. Personal privacy laws -- noise statutes. I planned to go to Law School after T graduate, but now it looks like I won't have enough money to go to college.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: (coldly) Well, the world needs ditch diggers, too. Danny nods politely, then makes a face behind Smails' bac

dialogues.speaker: THE FIRST GREEN
dialogues.text: The Bishop sinks his putt as Spaulding lines up a fifteen footer,

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: (to Smails) Put me down for a five. Goofy holds up eight fingers behind the Bishop's back for Danny to see. SPAULDING putts and misses.

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: ~ Hell! He quickly putts again and misses again.

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: Damn!

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: (admonishing him) Easy, son.

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: Well, that Caddy's right in my line. {to Danny) Move over, stupid! Danny moves away slowly and watches, Spaulding misses aga picks up a "gimme", and storms off the green.

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: (practically running Danny down) Get out of my way.

dialogues.speaker: LINOUVTALLIGE COG
dialogues.text: eee  53

dialogues.speaker: DANNY'S FOOT
dialogues.text: Spaulding's cart wheel rolls over Danny's foot.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He glowers at Spaulding, shoulders the golf bag he’s carr and walks toward the second tee.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK'S FOURSOME
dialogues.text: They march toward the first green. Czernak is drawing a b from a tap built into his golf bag. He's entertaining Sco and Gatsby by jazzing the caddies, Tony and Joey.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: You guys really know how to carry golf bags. This is considered skilled labor for Italians, isn't it? What else can you do?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I know how to make a Polack by rubbin' two pieces of shit together. Czernak stops at his ball on the fringe of the green and takes out a putter equipped with a Norden bombsight.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, I'm Hungarian ~- not Polish.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Then I need three. Czernak lines up his putt and adjusts the bombsight.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (remembering Tony) Hey! The bartender! You poured me a drink last night.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: I poured ya about thirty, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (laughing, taps his ball) Bombs away!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The ball. curves toward the hole and drops.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Boom! (as it drops) : (imitates big explosion)

dialogues.speaker: THE FOURTH TEE
dialogues.text: Smails gazes at a row of new ranch homes across from the course, visible from the elevation of the tec.

dialogues.speaker: SMATILS
dialogues.text: You know, Reverend, when we started Bushwood, you couldn't see a single house from here. We called it a ‘country club’ because it was in the country. Now look! They're almost on top of us.

dialogues.speaker: BEEPER AND DANNY
dialogues.text: The Bishop tees off in the background.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: 1 think surgeons are like the fighter pilots of a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: BEEPER
dialogues.text: (slipping on his aviator sunglasses) Hum. Interesting analogy.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: IT want to go to Medical School, but right now my parent's can't afford to send me to college even.

dialogues.speaker: BEEPER
dialogues.text: Wait! I know a way a college-bound fellow could pick up some money fast.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (excited) You do?

dialogues.speaker: BEEPER
dialogues.text: Yes! My regular man is sick and L need someone to mow my lawn. Sunday morning. I'11 make it well worth your while. Beeper walks off to the tee. Danny gives him the finger behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: THE THIRD GREEN
dialogues.text: Czernak spies the row of ranch houses.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (yelling to his party) Hey! Look at all those houses! I bet they'd love a great shopping mall right here! Condos over there -- (he gestures) -- plenty of parking. Racquethall, adult twin theaters -- a kiddie play- ground. We'll make a fortune, believe me. Y'know, country clubs and cemeteries are the biggest wasters of prime real estate. Dead people don't wanna be buried these days -- ecology, right? An™ you know who belongs to country clubs -- the newly wed and the nearly dead.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: He's on the fourteenth fairway about to hit. Danny stands with the Bishop watching him.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: I'll tell you, son, my real love is working with young people like you down at our new Youtheran Center. You ought to stop by some time.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I've often thought of entering the priesthood.

dialogues.speaker: BISHOP
dialogues.text: You're Catholic? (Danny nods) Oh well...then you -- uh -- can’t come.

dialogues.speaker: SEVENTEENTH TEE
dialogues.text: Czernak, Tony and Joey are watching a Cubs’ baseball game on a five-inch TV screen built into Czernak's golf bag. Al is a little bushed, consequently relaxed and reflectiv

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (reminiscing) -~ IT used to steal a lot of stuff when J was a kid. Turned out to be a good practice for the business world. Growing up on the street is the best education you can get. (sees something on the fairway) Hey, look! A groundhog!

dialogues.speaker: A MOLE
dialogues.text: It streaks across the fairway chased by a bizarre-looking Sandy, the groundskeeper, follows with a butterfly net. T mole dives into a hole just ahead of the snarling dog.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: He shouts to Sandy.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sandy! Who's the pooch?

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: He stands by the hole as the dog digs frantically.

dialogues.speaker: SANDY
dialogues.text: (shouting) It's a Scottish Molehound! Best damn rodent dog in the world. The mole pops out of another hole a few feet away. The do leaps at it as Sandy lunges with the net. He nets the dog which goes berserk, snarling and yapping in the net as th mole scurries away.

dialogues.speaker: ETGHTEENTH GREEN
dialogues.text: Smails is just about to putt when he sees the molehound i the distance, fighting with the groundskeeper.

dialogues.speaker: SMALLS
dialogues.text: (rattled) What now!

dialogues.speaker: THE FAIRWAY
dialogues.text: Czernak shouts at Smails as he locates his ball.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (bellows) Hey, Smells! Thousand bucks you miss that putt.

dialogues.speaker: THE GREEN
dialogues.text: Smails has had it. . Ne turns red and looks up to see tha a number of people have stopped to watch him putt. Beside Danny and Goofy, Dr. Beeper and the Bishop, a few other players and caddies who just finished are waiting for him to putt, Also, a few women in tennis clothes on their way to the clubhouse patio have stopped to watch.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: He concentrates, taps the ball, and misses. The spectator groan sympathetically. In a rage he hurls his putter.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY AND GCOOOFY
dialogues.text: Their eyes follow the club as it sails over a tall hedger A woman screams, and a crash is heard.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLUBHOUSE PATIO
dialogues.text: Judge Smails is apologizing to a startled crowd as Dr. RB revives a stunned WOMAN MEMBER, An umbrella table is torn

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S HUSBAND
dialogues.text: (angry) Well, if you didn't throw it, how did it get here?

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: It slipped out of my hand.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  58

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Club Manager RICHARD RICHARDS runs up.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: What seems to be the trouble?

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: He almost killed my wife with his club!

dialogues.speaker: SMALLS
dialogues.text: It-was an accident -- it slipped.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (stepping in) I noticed your grips were worn -- I should've mentioned it to you, sir. Sam could put some stick'em on then for you.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: (to Danny - grateful) Good idea. Next time be more careful. (to angry husband) I'm really terribly sorry about this -- I'll sign for your lunch, all right? (to Manager) And I'll sign for the umbrella.

dialogues.speaker: . MANAGER
dialogues.text: Oh no, Judge -- if it was an accident -~ no need.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Fine. (signals waiter) A double scotch-and-soda over there. (to Danny) Danny, come over to the table and I'll sign your card.

dialogues.speaker: A TABLE
dialogues.text: Danny stands by as Smails signs his card. Danny knows he' onto something.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: Thanks for your help back there. You're a fine caddy and that's something to be proud of. Say, did you know that we're awarding another Caddy Scholarship this year?

dialogues.speaker: _ DANNY
dialogues.text: Yes, I have heard something about it, but my grades in high school weren't actually that outstanding.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: There are more important things than grades, son. You just turn in an application and let me take care of the rest. che gets up) By the way, I'm launching my new sloop at the Yacht Club Sunday afternoon. A lot of the young people will be there. Why don't you join us?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: That sounds great, sir. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: (g00d-humored) And you tell Ty Webb that I'm gunning for him. If he's that good, I want to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke is vacuuming the rug when Spaulding approaches him. Smoke turns off the machine.

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: (confidentially) Uh -- Westinghouse, do you know where I could get any -- stuff?

dialogues.speaker: SMOKE
dialogues.text: (looking around) Well, Master Spaulding, I might be able to get some fine Bongolese later to day for seventy-five.

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: Seventy-five!

dialogues.speaker: SMOKE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) It's the best. Spaulding reluctantly hands Smake the cash and splits.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
