dialogues.text: Danny browses around an exclusive habadashery and stops to admire an elegant Ivy League suit on a mannequin. A SALESMAN apperas at his shoulder and notes Danny's fade jeans and battered jacket

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: (icily) Is there something you want?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (feigning disinterest) No. (disdainfully fingers the suit material) Not is this is the best you've got.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: (suddenly obsequious) Of course not, sir! If you'll just come with me and slip off your -- uh -- jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny comes out with several bags and boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two-story converted stable has the feeling of an 18th Century English farm -- grasscutting equipment, gardening tools and piles of mulch litter the courtyard. A potting shed is just opposite.

dialogues.speaker: SMOKE
dialogues.text: He's pulling dead, dry weeds out of the ground and stuffi them into a plastic baggie. He slips away as Danny comes walking across the yard carrying a golf bag.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He stops and turns at the sound of a voice. MAGGIE (v.o.) (calls musically) Oh Danny boy -- He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: She's leaning over the railing of a balcony in her unifor smiling down at him. You can see right up her skirt.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGTE
dialogues.text: Can I give you a hand with your bag?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: . (smiles) Hi Mag.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, so it's Mag now? (sings) Mary Margaret Mag the Hag, another bag?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (laughing) Cut it out. i can see up your dress.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (naughty) I know. Come on up. Danny looks around nervously, then trots up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie lies seductively on the bed in her wmiform and whi shoes. Her room is simple but tidy and charming. Photos o home and family occupy places of honor atop her desk and dresser along with a major standing crucifix, a blow drye and a glass snowball souvenir from Disneyworld. Danny sits down on the bed and they kiss.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: How's your little friend?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (unbuttoning her uniform) Who?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maggie starts to pull his T-shirt off but deliberately ge it stuck over his head, pinning his arms.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (enjoying making him struggle) Lacey Overalls -- the girl with the enormous appetite for butter. Danny yanks on his shirt and tears it nearly in half.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She's not my friend. It's the Judge I'm after.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGTE
dialogues.text: (rueful) Oh, that one. When I get home I'm going to send him a letter bomb.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (weakly) He's really not that bad, y'know.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (pulling back) You traitor! Tony D'Annunzio needs money worse than you do but he'd never go oiling up to the Judge like that.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well Tony doesn't want to go to college. He didn't even want to go to grade school.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: That doesn't make you better than him. They lie together in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Who told you Lacey's a whore? Maggie shoves him off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 62' Chevy stationwagon with rusting fake wood panelling is parked in the driveway. Church bells are ringing all around the neighborhood, All the Noonan kids come running out the side door of the house dressed for church. They pile into the wagon, fighting for good scats, jumping in and out of the windows like a barrel of monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mrs. Noonan comes out last in her best Sunday outfit, inc white gloves and hat with veil. She takes her accustomed place in the front seat. Panny closes the door for her th runs around to the driver's seat. He backs out of the dri fast and speeds off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: Danny, don't drive so fast, dear. Andy, honey, don't pick that. It'll fall off by itself.

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE WAGON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Noonan is about to get out, but stops. Danny is desp to get going.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: (to Danny) It wouldn't kill you to go to Mass, you know.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I went last night! They had a special midnight Mass for people with summer jobs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I bet!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I gotta deliver papers, I gotta mow Beeper's lawn and I'm -- .

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: ~-going to a party at the Yacht Club. i know. Hooray for you. Remind your father to pick us up after Mass, all right?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You told me a thousand times!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. NOONAN
dialogues.text: (getting out) And you'll still forget. She closes the door and Nanny peels away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, NOONAN GARAGE
dialogues.text: Danny and Andy are loading the wagon with heavy stacks of fat Sunday papers.

dialogues.speaker: ANDY
dialogues.text: (reluctant) We gotta tie ‘em better!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I don't have time. let's go. He jumps behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: BACK DOOR
dialogues.text: Mr. Noonan comes out carrying his golf bag on a cart, gol shoes and a bag lunch. He's dressed to play golf, Tooking snazzier and happier than we've seen him. The car speeds off down the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: MR. NOONAN
dialogues.text: (seeing his trans- portation disappear) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chevy wagon speeds down the street. Andy whips papers out of the open tailgate.

dialogues.speaker: A FRONT DOOR ON THE STREET
dialogues.text: A MAN in a bathrobe opens his front door to get his newsp He looks at his own lawn in shock, then turns and looks u street.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET
dialogues.text: The front lawns on both sides are almost covered with a m of papers swirling in the summer breeze. A dog chases the Chevy wagon as it squeals around the corner and disappear

dialogues.speaker: DR. BEEPER'S MATLBOX
dialogues.text: The mailbox is a beautiful replica of a country home with the name “Beeper, M.D.'' painted neatly on it,

dialogues.speaker: DR. BEEPER'S LAWN
dialogues.text: It's easily seven rolling acres of carefully landscaped l gardens, fountains, statuary and topiary. The grass is a foot high. A very small, rusty, push-mower stands unatten — LENOUYTALLIGE. CGh CONTINUED  65

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: in the middle of the vast, uncut expanse. A mechanical ro is heard approaching.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BEEPER'S MAILBOX
dialogues.text: It begins to vibrate as a monstrous machine passes.

dialogues.speaker: THE GREENSKEEPER'S TRACTOR-MOWER
dialogues.text: Danny sits atop the mechanical monster we saw on the golf course and steers it up Beeper's driveway. We manhandles thing onto the spacious lawn and cuts the grass with incr efficiency, doing the whole job in one sweeping circuit of the grounds.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He turns around to admire the wonderful job he's done whe suddenly he's clotheslined by a line of laundry that catc him by the neck and pulls him off the mower. A BLACK MAID runs out of the house yelling at him.

dialogues.speaker: THE MOWER
dialogues.text: Danny and the Maid watch in horror as the unattended mowe runs over a carefully sculpted hedge and chops it up like a Vegematic.

dialogues.speaker: NEXT DOOR
dialogues.text: Beeper's neighbors are having an elegant lawn party. Sudd they hear the roar of a motor and turn to see the mower e way through a tall thick hedge and right into their yard. The guests run screaming as the mower runs right over a l buffet table sending up a shower of chopped cold cuts. Th it runs over a bed of carefully planted tulips and exits yard by eating through the hedge on the other side. The guests look after it stunned as Danny comes through the n opening from keeper's yard. He trots through the debris, bowing politely to everyone and disappears through the ne cut exit on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: A GAS STATION
dialogues.text: Danny's stationwagon pulls up to the pumps. He jumps out, sweating and nervous, shouts something to the gas station attendant and dashes into the Men's Room carrying a Dop kit and the boxes from the Campus Shoppe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny exits the grungy Men's Room looking like the Prince of Whales in a blazer, white pants, shoes and ascot. He sports a whie yachting cap. He gives the amazed attendant a dollar and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: YACHT CLUB PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Danny drives into the lot and looks around at the expensi Mercedes, Cadillacs and shining sports cars parked in the lot. Danny starts to back out when a red-jacketed parking attendant jogs over, staring at the smcking heap. He trie to open the door for Danny, but the handle comes off in h hand.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's a classic. My father's having it restored for his collection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny enters a large beamed room decorated with real ship bulls, models and pennants. A local rock band is playing "More" amidst a crowd of madras and cranberry pants types Danny looks around uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: She and her friends are dancing, all dressed very casuall in a variety of T-shirts, jeans and cut-offs. Lacey is dancing with a long-haired suburban freak, They all turn and stare at Danny, standing stiffly at the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: NOBLE
dialogues.text: He looks like Dick Cavett. They all giggle and smirk,

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He pulls his yachting cap down over his eyes and shrinks toward the bar. Some unkind WOLF WHISTLES and APPLAUSE is heard from the young rich set. Danny reaches for a glass white wine on a tray, but a hand clamps down on his shoul scaring him so mu “OMB WA TALL ICE Cabg °° of wine. pawen  67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beeper has his creepy hand on Danny's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BEEPER
dialogues.text: Hello, son. How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Uh -- the lawn looks great. (Beeper's beeper beeps; a ship's whistle is heard)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMAILS
dialogues.text: She stands in front of the band, shushing them. She blows a gold bosun's pipe strung around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMAILS
dialogues.text: All right, children, we're launching the sloop now -~ you can shake your booties down on the dock. The young people groan.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMAILS
dialogues.text: Go on, scamper! (claps hands)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY AND BEEPER
dialogues.text: Danny's standing around nervously. He turns to leave, onl to encounter Noble Noyes and Spaulding Smails.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS III
dialogues.text: Ahoy, polloi. Hey, Noonan, whadja just come from -- a scotch ad?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Eat it.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMALLS
dialogues.text: walks by and stops.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMAILS
dialogues.text: My, what a nice-looking young man! You're from Bushwood, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: He's not a member -- he's a caddy, Gramma,

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (quickly) Judge Smails invited me yesterday at the Club.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMAILS
dialogues.text: Oh yes, the boy who wants to be in the Senate. Too bad more of your generation don't follow your example, young man -- (to Spaulding) You look like boogies! Now scamper! They leave. Danny stands there for an uncomfortable momen with Mrs. Smails.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (gulping, offers her his arm) May I escort you out, ma'am? Mrs. Smails gasps with delight and takes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMAILS
dialogues.text: You are a nice young man! Danny pulls his cap even lower over his eyes and starts t walk out with her. Judge Smails appears dressed just like Danny. CHUCK SHICK, an athletic young man, is with him.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: (exuberant) Hold on, son! Trying to make time with my best girl? Danny looks at Mrs. Smails and manages a sickly smile.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Thank you for inviting me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: Have you met Chuck Shick, Danny? Chuck is clerking for me this summer until he passes the bar. (they shake hands) Danny's going to Law School, too, Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Really? You going to Harvard?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (quietly) St. Copious.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: St. Copious of Northern Nebraska. They have an excellent golf program --~-

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: (to Danny) Speaking of golf, .I've done some checking up on you, son. TI hear you're quite a golfer yourself. Danny won our Caddy tournament two years in a row. Gonna win it again this year, Senator? the winks)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm going to try, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: That's the spirit. See you on deck. Smails salutes Danny and walks off with Chuck and Mrs. Sm LACEY walks up to Danny with her hairy friend, TERRY.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Hey, Cary Grant -- want to get high?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Hey, I only got a little.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Then fart off, okay, Terry? Terry splits angrily. Lacey smirks at Danny's outfit.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I guess I'm a little overdressed.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) It depends on what's underneath.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What? She sighs and pulls him toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE MARINA
dialogues.text: Most of the boats are out on the lake, but a few beautifu yachts are still in their slips.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SMAILS' SLOOP
dialogues.text: The Judge is peevishly supervising two dock workers. They are finishing the slip-rails under the hull of Smails' ne thirty-foot racing sloop, The Bluebird. Some members watc with mild interest.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: Lovely day for a launch, isn't it? Easy! Easy! Shoes off if you're coming aboard.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHORE
dialogues.text: Spaudling, Noble and Terry lounge on the shore passing a large joint.

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: Did you see that kid? (passes a joint) He's not even a member.

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: He tried to do my blow.

dialogues.speaker: NOBLE
dialogues.text: Hey, this reminds me a little of the Bosphorous. Mummy took us last year when Daddy flipped out.

dialogues.speaker: SPAUDLING
dialogues.text: No one goes there anymore -- it's been totally ruined by rich Americans. Europe's been ruined for years...

dialogues.speaker: TERRY
dialogues.text: They ruined Morocco, man. No one goes there anymore -- too many plastic hippies.

dialogues.speaker: NOBLE
dialogues.text: (inspecting joint and coughing) Hey, what kind of shit is this?

dialogues.speaker: SPAULDING
dialogues.text: It's the best, man. Got it from a Negro. It comes on slow -- you're probably so high already you don't even know it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: [ONOUTTALLIGECGRMG == tS”  71

dialogues.speaker: TERRY AND NOBLE
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMATLS
dialogues.text: She blows her whistle and beckons the guests to gather on floating docks near the sloop.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMATLS
dialogues.text: All right, everybody! It's time! She takes a champagne bottle as the Judge prepares a litt speech from the boat. Polite applause.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE SMAILS
dialogues.text: Thank you, everyone -- it's been many years and, frankly, many dollars to reach this point -- (polite laughter)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY AND LACEY
dialogues.text: She's sitting next to him on a cushioned lounge on the pa _ reading his palm. Danny has now shed his blazer and rol his sleeves, .

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: ..-And this is your fate line. You look like you're going to make a lot of money when you're older ---

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (interested) Oh yeah? When? How?

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Qlooking closer) Not for a few years yet -- could be either the market or a game show. And this is your saliva line... (she licks his hand slowly)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What does that tell? She continues to lick his wrist and up his arm, Danny alm swoons,.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: How hot I can get you. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: THE SLOOP
dialogues.text: Mrs. Smails winds up with a champagne bottle.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SMAILS
dialogues.text: I hereby christen thee 'The Bluebird.' She smashes her champagne bottle down. and breaks the bow off the boat without breaking the bottle. The boat begins slide into the water.

dialogues.speaker: SMATLS
dialogues.text: (aghast) Pookie!

dialogues.speaker: A HUGE PAIR OF BINOCULARS
dialogues.text: A familiar voice booms above a loud roar, blaring music and laughter. CZERNAK (v.0.) It's my buddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can see Smails gesticulating wildly as his sloop slide into the water. CZERNAK (v.0.) (yelling orders) Hard right turn! All ahead all the engines! Go over there!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY AND LACEY
dialogues.text: Lacey is rubbing the back of Danny's neck, touching his nose with hers lightly.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Do you like me?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (weak) Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: More than being a Senator?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Then say it.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I like you more than being in the Senate.

dialogues.speaker: THE SLOOP
dialogues.text: The sloop docks off shore with Smails aboard. The guests remove their shoes and follow the small boat along the tw floating docks, giggling drunkenly.

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: (holding his bowsprit) God damnit! Where's the first mate? Somebody get a bottle of glue!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY AND LACEY
dialogues.text: She's drawing it out, tcasing.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: More than being President of the world?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: More than being President of the world.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Wow. She leans over to kiss Danny's trembling lips. Suddenly t is a huge GRONNK of notes that sound like an ice cream tr for dinosaurs. They turn ot the camera, interrupting the kiss.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here. She takes his hand and leads him off.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK'S BOAT
dialogues.text: The enormous hull roars by the camera. The whole boat has been "customized" with chromed horns, lamed life rings, futuristic radar and a snarling "flying tiger' face paint on the prow. We read the name, ‘Thunderball II" on the side as its entire length roars by, throwing up a huge wa

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: He's on the bridge in a loud Hawaiian shirt, now at the w of his 110-foot power pleasure cruiser. White-jacketed se tend to the Fun Couples and other guests, including bikin

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: clad cuties. They drink and wave to the Yacht Club partie Loud music.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (through bullhorn) Hey, Smails! My dinghy's bigger than your whole boat! Ha ha ha!

dialogues.speaker: SMATLS
dialogues.text: He waves off Czernak's enormous craft.

dialogues.speaker: SMATLS
dialogues.text: Go away! Go away! Heave off!

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Struggling with the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: (through bullhorn) Save me a parking place. I'm comin' in! Pp & Pp He hits a horn that blares out "Mary Had a Little Lamb".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lacey pets into a Mercedes 450SL. Danny gawks at the car.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Would you rather take your car? Danny's Chevy wagon is right behind her.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (reaching) No -- my back speakers are out.

dialogues.speaker: THE MARINA
dialogues.text: Czernak's giant vessel slams into the small harbor, sides a bell buoy, snaps a line of floats and snage the line of dockside fisherman, yanking him into the water.

dialogues.speaker: A SMALL ROWBOAT
dialogues.text: Terrified people leap from the craft as Czernak's bow sli it neatly in half.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: He spins the wheel in both directions, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Okay, let's back ‘er up. (looks around) Where's the rearview mirror?

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK'S BOAT
dialogues.text: It's banging into boats on every side like a bull in a ch shop, and steams right into the Yacht Club dock.

dialogues.speaker: THE YACHT CLUB DOCK
dialogues.text: Piled shoes begin to fall in the water as the GUESTS try balance on the bobbing, teetering platforms and slide int the water shrieking.

dialogues.speaker: A MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN
dialogues.text: My hair! My hair!

dialogues.speaker: SMAILS
dialogues.text: He looks up in terror at Czernak's looming hull.

dialogues.speaker: SMALLS
dialogues.text: (furious) Stop! Czernak leans over the bridge and waves at Smails.

dialogues.speaker: CZERNAK
dialogues.text: Oaky! Drop anchor! Suddenly, Czernak's huge anchor CRASHES down through the of Smail's boat. It starts to sink with Smails aboard loo like the Captain of the Titanic.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY'S CAR
dialogues.text: She's driving incredibly fast down winding country roads.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: You scared?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (exhilarated) Yeah

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Me, too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny and Lacey are picking their way through lovely, dar woods. Afternoon sunlight is filtering through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Butterflies flutter around brightly-colored wildflowers a delicate ferns.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Wanna do some real MDA?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Pardon me?

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: MDA -- If got it from a guy I know in medical school. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (taking a pill) You sure this is okay?

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Oh, it's all bad for you. Danny gags in mid-swallow. Lacey sees a deer and touches Danny's hand to still him.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Wow -~ a deer!

dialogues.speaker: A BUBBLING BROOK BY A TINY WATERFALL
dialogues.text: Danny and Lacey are dabbling their feet in the cool water in dappled sunlight. They stare intently at the water. A is croaking.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (awed) It looks like a painting.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: Monet.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Right. Him definitely. Cpoints) Look! A BEAUTIFUL DRAGONFLY hovers. and skips above the water.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: It looks like jewelry that's alive,

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. She leans on Danny.

dialogues.speaker: LACEY
dialogues.text: It's nice here. It reminds me of the Black Forest.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lacey's feet become entangled with Danny's.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY

I learned quick - if you want something take it. Everybody who was ever anybody did the same thing. Look at the Indians, for Christ sake! dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: _ fNOMMVTALLIGE. CGkG  134

dialogues.speaker: THE NOONAN KIDS
dialogues.text: They are stunned. MRS. NOONAN comes in with a steaming bo of broccoli.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: ....two thousand....three thousand.... She drops the bowl.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY'S NEIGHBORHOOD
dialogues.text: DANNY (v.0.) Let's see -- uh -- twelve thousand --an' those are all G-notes....uh so that's twenny-three thousand... twenny-four...I got some quarters here.

dialogues.speaker: THE SKY
dialogues.text: A jumbo jet roars through the frame.

dialogues.speaker: THE AIRPORT
dialogues.text: Wearing a shorter haircut,tie, shined shocs and carrying suitcases, Danny is hugging and kissing each of his famil members. His tearful, proud mother hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: Flight number forty-two for Omaha, Nebraska, now boarding at Gate forty-six. Danny breaks free and walks outside to his plane. He look back to see a PRETTY GIRL going through another gate mark "AIR JAMAICA".

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: She smiles at Danny, making a face of disappointment that they are going two different ways.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He does the same.

dialogues.speaker: THE OBSERVATION WINDOW
dialogues.text: All the Noonan's are yelling and waving and jostling the observers.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He waves back. He glances at the girl.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Her line starts to move out her plane. She has a GOLF BAG with her. She looks back at Danny.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: He looks at her, hypnotized.

dialogues.speaker: MASTER OF BOTH PLANES QUEUES
dialogues.text: Danny breaks and trots over to the Air Jamaica line. The PRETTY GIRL is just about to pick up her golf bag whe Danny grabs it and slings it easily over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Let me show you how it's done. They go up the steps together, talking and laughing as th board the airplane.
